info.name: Full Fabric APIs
info.description:
Welcome to the Full Fabric Foundation CRM APIs documentation.

Full Fabric uses HTTP verbs and a RESTful endpoint structure.

Request and response payloads are formatted as JSON.

# API versions

## What is my API version?

Your API version controls the API you see (e.g. what properties you  
see in responses, what parameters youâ€™re permitted to send in requests,  
etc.).

When we change the API in a backwards-incompatible way, we release a new dated version.

## Specifying API version

All requests require an API version. You can specify a version via the X-API-Version or Accept header as below

```
X-API-Version: 2021-04-13
Accept: application/json;version=2021-04-13

 ```

# Authentication

Authenticate your account when using the API by including your secret API token in the request. Your API tokens carry many privileges, so be sure to keep them secret! Do not share your secret API tokens in publicly accessible areas, client-side code, and so forth.

All API requests must be made over HTTPS. Calls made over plain HTTP will fail. API requests without authentication will also fail.

## Authentication via the FF-Auth header

Set a FF-Auth header with your secret API token to authenticate the request.

``` shell
curl https://_.fullfabric.com/apis/profiles/profiles/57232561dfc41880050001de \
  -H "Accept: application/json; version=2021-04-13" \
  -H "FF-Auth: TOKEN"

 ```

# Requests

Full Fabric uses HTTP verbs and a RESTful endpoint structure. Request and response payloads are formatted as JSON.

``` shell
curl \
  --request GET \
  --url https://_.fullfabric.com/apis/profiles/profiles/ID \
  --header 'Accept: application/json;version=2021-04-13' \
  --header 'FF-Auth: TOKEN'

 ```

## Common request headers

| **Name** | **Type** | **Default** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| FF-Auth | string | `[user token]` |
| Accept | string | `application/json;version=[api version]` |

# Errors

Full Fabric uses conventional HTTP response codes to indicate the success or failure of an API request. In general, codes in the 2xx range indicate success, codes in the 4xx range indicate an error that failed given the information provided (e.g., a required parameter was omitted, a charge failed, etc.), and codes in the 5xx range indicate an error with our servers (these are rare).

## HTTP status code summary

```
200 - OK: Everything worked as expected.
400 - Bad Request: The request was unacceptable, often due to missing a required parameter.
401 - Unauthorized: No valid API key provided.
402 - Request Failed: The parameters were valid but the request failed.
404 - Not Found: The requested resource doesn't exist.
422 - Unprocessable Entity: The request is understood but invalid, often due to failed validation.
429 - Too Many Requests: Too many requests hit the API too quickly.
50x - Server Errors: Something went wrong on our end. (These are rare.)

 ```

## Dealing with API errors

You may find that you've encountered successive errors when trying to access the API.

Rather than ignore repeated 4xx and 5xx status codes, you should ensure that you're correctly interacting with the API. For example, if an endpoint requests a string and you're passing it a numeric value, you're going to receive a validation error, and your call won't succeed. Similarly, attempting to access an unauthorized or nonexistent endpoint will result in a 4xx error.

Intentionally ignoring repeated validation errors may result in the suspension of your app for abuse.

# Rate limiting

For API requests using token-based authentication, you can make up to 5000 requests per hour.

The maximum number of requests you are permitted to make

- per 8 seconds is 20
- per 60 seconds is 90
- per 3600 seconds is 5000
    

## Abuse rate limits

In order to maintain the quality of the service, additional rate limits may apply to some actions when using the API. For example, using the API to rapidly, polling aggressively, making multiple concurrent requests, or repeatedly request data that is computationally expensive may result in abuse rate limiting.

To avoid hitting this limit, you should ensure your application follows the guidelines below:

- make requests for a single token serially. Do not make requests for a single token concurrently.
- if you're making a large number of POST, PATCH, PUT, or DELETE requests for a single token, wait at least one second between each request.
- when you have been limited, use the Retry-After response header to slow down. The value of the Retry-After header will always be an integer, representing the number of seconds until the rate limiting expires.

request.description:
This request allows you to create a new profile.

### **Mandatory fields**

The `first_name`, `last_name` and `email` fields are mandatory for creating a profile.

A privacy policy or data processing consent policy acceptance is mandatory if your institution has either policy published. The marketing policy acceptance is not mandatory.

## **Field types**

Please find a list of different field types below and the formats which they require.

### **Policies**

The data processing consent, privacy policy and marketing policy require all of the following information in the format below.

``` json
"policies": {
        "data_processing_consent_accept": "true",
        "data_processing_consent_date": "2021-04-13",
        "data_processing_consent_source": "phone call with Barbara Heinz",
        "privacy_policy_accept": "true",
        "privacy_policy_source": "Written form at the open day event",
        "privacy_policy_date": "2021-04-14",
        "marketing_policy_accept": "true",
        "marketing_policy_date": "2021-04-15",
        "marketing_policy_options": "email, phone",
        "marketing_policy_source": "Written form at the open day event"
    }

```

### **Single line text/ paragraph text/ email/ drop down fields**

For "single line text", "paragraph text", "email", "smart email" and drop down fields you can specify the value as string. E.g `first_name: "John"`.

### **Number fields**

For "number" fields you can provide either a number or a string with a number.

### **Date fields**

For "date" fields, you must indicate a date on a parsable format. This includes "yyyy-mm-dd" and a UNIX timestamp in milliseconds.

### **Address fields**

For "address" fields you must provide an object that follows the address default schema, which is:

``` json
{
  "line_1": "string",
  "line_2": "string",
  "line_3": "string",
  "post_code": "string",
  "city": "string",
  "state": "string",
  "country": "string with country name as by ISO 3166"
}

```

### **Check box fields**

For "check box" fields, provide an array with the values to be checked. E.g: `__favorite_animals: ["Dog", "Cat"]`

### **File upload fields**

For "file upload fields" field you should use a form-data body. To specify multiple file uploads for the same field (if it is a multi-file upload field) you should specify your form data keys like `profile[__field_name][]`

request.description:
Allows updating the values of specific fields on a profile.

You can update any type of field in the profile's schema. Check [documentation for the POST request](#5704f27c-ee12-4108-9f3b-9e1383d3133d) to know how each type of field should be specified in your request.

Note that to update a file upload field you should use a form-data body.

Only fields which are part of the profile schema are taken into account, whereas non-existent fields are ignored.

request.description:
##### Introduction

This subscription allows you to set up a real-time integration between Full Fabric and your other systems, whereby you are notified whenever a relevant profile state change occurs. Through a subscription, for example, you could be informed whenever a profile reaches a certain state e.g. applicant::submitted, student::enrolled. Then afterwards you can retrieve the profile and application information and push it to your other system.

##### Usage

When the role of a profile in any class or course changes from the state specified in `initial_state_and_substate` to the one in the `state_and_substate` the specified `url` is notified via a POST request with a JSON object as the body in the following format:

``` json
{
  "role_id": "id_as_string", // ID of the role that changed state
  "profile_id": "id_as_string", // ID of the profile which role was updated
  "context_id": "id_as_string", // ID of the context which the role is in (e.g: ID of the class)
  "previous_state_and_substate": "string", // previous state of the role before this notification
  "state_and_substate": "string" // current state of the role
}

```

Note that both `intial_state_and_substate` and `state_and_substate` are optional attributes in the request's body.

If you only provide the `initial_state_and_substate`, the specified url will be notified whenever a profile with a role in that state updates to any other state.

If you only provide the `state_and_substate`, the specified url will be notified whenever any profile's role reaches that state, from whatever state it was in previously.

If you provide neither, then the specified url will be notified whenever any profile role state is changed.

response.name: 200 Successful request

request.description:
## Introduction

This subscription allows you to set up a real-time integration between Full Fabric and your other systems, whereby you are notified whenever a user submits a filled out form. Then afterwards you can retrieve the values on that form submission, and push it to your other system.

## Usage

When a user makes a form submission to the form specified by the `form_id` param, the specified `url` is notified via a POST request with a JSON object as the body in the following format:

```
{
  "id": "id_as_string", // ID of the form submission 
  "submitted_at": "date_in_seconds", // Date when the answer to the form was submitted. The date is a UNIX timestamp in seconds
  "[form_fields]": "[values_according_to_schema]", // Key value pairs with the fields specified in the form schema, and the values in the due format
}

```

We currently allow sorting by: created_at, start_date, end_date, start_registrations_date and end_registrations_date
This filter will define the sorting order of the events returned, it must be one of: asc, desc

request.description:
The endpoint makes an HTTP GET request to retrieve a list of events. The request includes query parameters for limiting the number of results, skipping a certain number of results, and sorting the results in ascending order.

The response is a JSON array containing objects representing events. Each event object includes the following properties:

- id (string): The unique identifier of the event.
    
- name (string): The name or title of the event.
    
- created_by_id (string): The unique identifier of the user who created the event.
    
- created_at (number): The timestamp indicating when the event was created.
    
- updated_at (number): The timestamp indicating when the event was last updated.
    
- start_date (number): The timestamp of the event's start date.
    
- end_date (number): The timestamp of the event's end date.
    
- start_registrations_date (number): The timestamp indicating when registrations for the event start.
    
- end_registrations_date (number): The timestamp indicating when registrations for the event end, or null if there is no end date.
    
- timezone (string): The timezone in which the event takes place.
    
- location (string): The name or description of the event's location.
    
- address (string): The address of the event's location.
    
- views (number): The number of views or visits the event has received.
    
- number_of_responses (number): The total number of responses received for the event.
    
- number_of_attendees (number): The total number of attendees for the event.
    
- number_of_yes (number): The number of "yes" responses received for the event.
    
- number_of_maybe (number): The number of "maybe" responses received for the event.
    
- number_of_no (number): The number of "no" responses received for the event.
    
- team_ids (array of strings): An array of unique identifiers of teams associated with the event.
    

The response of this request can be documented as a JSON schema.

item.name: Add a payment plan to a profile

request.description:
Creates a payment plan based on a specified payment plan template, and associates it to a specific profile's role.

The context ID in the body of the request should be set as the context ID (the class id or unit id) of the profile's role to which the payment plan should be associated. For example, to associate the payment plan to a profile's role for the MBA - January 2022 class then the context ID should be set as the class ID.
Deletes a profile's payment plan.

item.description:
### Introduction to payment plan templates and payment plans A payment plan template is a default set of fees, from which a payment plan for a particular candidate profile can be created and then customised. A payment plan template fee can have: * An amount which is either: a fixed amount or a percentage of the product price minus the sum of fixed amount fees. * A due date which is either: a fixed date, or a date which is dependent on the product start date or creation of the payment plan on the candidate profile. ### Payment Plan Template Model | **Attribute** | **Type** | **Description** | | --- | --- | --- | | id | string | | | name | string | | | fees | array\[object{Fee}\] | Can be empty. See Fee model bellow. | ### Template's Fee Model | **Attribute** | **Type** | **Description** | | --- | --- | --- | | id | string | | | plan_id | string | ID of the payment plan template which the belongs to. | | type | \["amount", "percentage"\] | Specifies the type of fee, between a fee representing a percentage of a total of a product (e.g: class), or a fee with a specific amount. | | amount
| integer | Price, **in cents,** of the fee. Will only be used if **type** is `amount` | | percentage | float | A number between 0 and 1 representing the percentage of the fee. E.g: a 10% fee will be represented as 0.1. | | currency | string | Currency of the fee in currency code (ISO 4217). | | description | string | Brief description of the fee. | | date_type | \["fixed", "distance"\] | Specifies the type of due date for the fee, between a fixed date, or a date based on the distance in days to a specific event (see `days_from` bellow) | | due_date | integer {Unix timestamp} | The due date to be used if the `date_type` is `fixed`. | | days | integer | Number of days after event until fee is due. In effect only if `date_type` is `distance` | | days_from | \["after_payment_plan_creation", "before_context_start_date", "after_context_start_date"\] | Event from which to count the distance in days. In effect only if `date_type` is `distance` |

item.description:
These requests provide the same data as theÂ "Product overview"Â report in Full Fabric. These requests can be used for the purpose of business intelligence reporting with other systems such as Power BI.

These requests provide you with the evolution in the number of profiles in specific lifecycle states for specific products over time. This provides an indication of the marketing and admissions performance for products over time, and lets you understand for example how the number of admitted applicants increases over time.

It is possible to combine lifecycle states and products through the query parameters to attain the sum of the combinations.

For example \[\["prospect::qualified",Â "applicant::submitted"\]\] will provide the sum of qualified and submitted. The same functionality is possible with the classes parameter.

query.description: Required. A string of a role state as defined in settings.
Required. A string of a role state as defined in settings.
Required. ID of a class

request.description:
This request provides the same data as the "Product conversion" report in Full Fabric.

This request provides you with the conversion rate between two lifecycle states for a specific product.

This provides you with an indication of how successful your process is in converting your customers through your funnel from a lower lifecycle state to a higher lifecycle state.

In the response:

*   start_state_count is a count of number of profiles which had a role for the start lifecycle state at some point in time.
*   end_state_count is a count of number of profiles which had a role for the end lifecycle state at some point in time.
*   conversion_rate is a simple ratio between the end_state_count and the start_state_count.

item.name: Update a student's grades for a unit

request.description:
This request registers the profile on one or more courses on their transcript.

The request body can contain one or more courses and can include grade and state data. It can contain a mixture of both courses which are not on the transcript, and courses on the transcript which are unregistered.

If the course is not present on the transcript, then the course will be added to the transcript.

If the course is present on the transcript but the profile has not been registered to the course, then they will be registered to the course.

item.name: Create a transcript for a profile's role for a class

request.description:
Creates a transcript for a particular profile's role for a class. Please note that this request does not currently work for a profile's role for a course.

This request creates a transcript which contains all of the courses on the class study plan, and they are unregistered.

item.name: Add and register a profile to courses on their transcript

request.description:
This request adds and registers profiles to courses on their transcript.

The request body can contain a mixture of both courses which are not on the transcript, and courses on the transcript which are unregistered.

If the course is not present on the transcript, then the course will be added to the transcript.

If the course is present on the transcript but the profile has not been registered to the course, then they will be registered to the course.

If a course id is invalid then the request will fail at the point at which the invalid course id is reached. So for example if the third course id is invalid and the first two course ids are valid then the first two courses will be added and registered successfully.

item.name: Unregister a profile from multiple courses on their transcript

request.description: Unregisters registered courses on the transcript.
